sp.l: Directly gone, fled, shifted: what would you have me say?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well Gentlemen,
Wrong not my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: For your Dukedom
I will not be a knave Sir.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: He that is
A rot run in his blood.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: But hark ye Gentlemen,
Are ye sure ye had her here, did ye not dream this.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Have you your nose Sir?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Then we had her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Since you are so short, believe your having her
Shall suffer more construction.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Let it suffer,
But if I be not clear of all dishonour,
Or practice that may taint my reputation,
And ignorant of where this woman is,
Make me your Cities monster.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I believe ye.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I could lie with a witch now, to be revenged
Upon that Rascal did this.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Only thus much
I would desire your Grace, for my mind gives me
Before night yet she is yours: stop all opinion,
And let no anger out, till full cause call it,
Then every man's own work is to justify him,
And this day let us give to search: my man here
Tells me, by chance he saw out of a window
(Which place he has taken note of) such a face
As our old Landladies, he believes the same too,
And by her hood assures it: Let us first thither,
For she being found, all is ended.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come, for heavens sake,
And Fortune, if thou beest not ever turning,
If there be one firm step in all thy reelings,
Now settle it, and save my hopes: away friends.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With all my jewels?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: All Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And that money
I left in the trunk?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Trunk broke, and that gone too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Franscisco of the plot?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Gone with the wench too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The mighty pox go with them: belike they thought
I was no man of this world, and those trifles
Would but disturb my conscience.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sure they thought Sir,
You would not live to persecute them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whore and Fiddler,
Why, what a consort have they made? Hen and bacon?
Well my sweet Mistress, well good Madam martaile?
You that have hung about my neck, and licked me,
I will try how handsomely your Ladyship
Can hang upon a Gallows, there is your Master-piece;
But hark ye Sirrah, no imagination
Of where they should be?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: None Sir, yet we have searched
All places we suspected; I believe Sir,
They have taken towards the Ports.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Get me a conjurer,
One that can raise a water devil, I will port them;
Play at duck and drake with my money? take heed Fiddler;
I will dance ye by this hand, your Fiddlestick
I will grease of a new fashion, for presuming
To meddle with my de-gambos: get me a Conjurer.
Enquire me out a man that lets out devils:
None but my C clef serve your turn?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I know not --

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: In every street, Tom fool, any bleary-eyed people
With red heads, and flat noses can perform it;
Thou shalt know them by their half gowns and no breeches:
Mount my mare Fiddler? ha boy? up at first dash?
Sit sure, I will clap a nettle, and a smart one,
Shall make your filly firk: I will find Fiddler,
I will put you to your plunge boy: Sirrah meet me
Some two hours hence at home; In the mean time
Find out a conjurer and know his price,
How he will let his devils by the day out,
I will have them, if they be above ground.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Now bless me,
What a mad man is this? I must do something
To please his humour: such a man I will ask for,
And tell him where he is: but to come near him,
Or have anything to do with his don devils,
I thank my fear, I dare not, nor I will not.

body.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio, Fredrick, John, Peter, Servant with bottles.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Whether wilt thou lead us?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It is hard by sir.
And ten to one this wine goes thither.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Forward.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Are they grown so merry.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is most likely
She has heard of this good fortune, and determines
To wash her sorrows off.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It is so; that house sir
Is it: out of that window certainly
I saw my old Mistresses face.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: They are merry indeed,
Hark I here Music too.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Excellent Music.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Would I were even among them and alone now,
A palate for the purpose in a corner,
And good rich wine within me; what gay sport
Could I make in an hour now?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hark a voice too;
Let us not stir yet by any means.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Was this her own voice?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes sure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is a rare one.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The Song confirms her here too: for if ye mark it,
It spake of liberty, and free enjoying
The happy end of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Look ye there sir,
Do ye know that head?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is my good Landlady,
I find fear has done all this.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: She I swear,
And now do I know by the hanging of her hood,
She is parcel drunk: shall we go in?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not yet Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No, let them take their pleasure,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: When it is highest,
We will step in, and amaze them: peace more Music.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: This Music murders me; what blood have I now?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I should know that face.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: By this light it is he Fredrick,
That bred our first suspicions, the same fellow.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He that we overtook, and overheard too
Discoursing of Constantia.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Still the same;
Now he slips in.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She must be here Sir:
This is the very fellow, I told your Grace
We found upon the way; and what his talk was.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why, sure I know this fellow; yes, it is he,
Francisco, Antonio's Boy, a rare Musician,
He taught my Sister on the Lute, and is ever
(She loves his voice so well) about her: certain,
Without all doubt she is here: it must be so.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Here? that is no question: what should our hen of the game else
Do here without her? if she be not here
(I am so confident) let your Grace believe,
We two are arrant Rascals, and have abused ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I say so too.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Why there is the hood again now,
The guard that guides us; I know the fabric of it.
And know the old tree of that saddle yet, it was made of
A hunting hood, observe it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who shall enter?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I will make one.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I, another.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But so carry it,
That all her joys flow not together.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: If we told her,
Your Grace would none of her?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: By no means Seignior,
It would turn her wild, stark frantic.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Or assured her --

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nothing of that? starve nature? this ye may sir.
That the conditions of our fear yet stand
On nice and dangerous knittings: or that a little
I seem to doubt the child.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Would I could draw her
To hate your Grace with these things.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Come let us enter,
And now he sees me not, I will search her soundly.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now luck of all sides.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Doubt it not: more Music:
Sure she has heard some comfort.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yes, stand still sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This is the maddest song.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: To some strange melancholy she is laden with.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Now all the sport begins -- hark?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: They are amongst them,
The fears now, and the shakings?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Our old Lady
(Hark how they run) is even now at this instant
Ready to lose her head piece by Don Iohn,
Or creeping through a Cat hole.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Bring them down,
And you sir, follow me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He is angry with them,
I must not suffer this.
Bowl down the Bawd there
Old Erra mater: you Lady lechery
For the good will I bear to the game, most tenderly
Shall be lead out, and lashed.

body.stage: Enter Petruchio, Iohn, Whore, and Bawd, with Francisco.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is this Constantia?
Why Gentlemen? what do you mean? is this she?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.l: I am Constantia sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A Whore ye are sir.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.l: It is very true: I am a Whore indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: She will not lie yet, though she steal.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.l: A plain whore,
If you please to employ me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And an impudent --

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.l: Plain dealing now is impudence.
One if you will sir, can show ye as much sport
In one half hour, and with as much variety,
As a far wiser woman can in half a year:
For there my way lies.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is she not drunk too?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.l: A little gilded over sir,
Old sack, old sack boys.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: This is salient.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: A brave bold quean.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is this your certainty?
Do ye know the man ye wrong thus, Gentlemen?
Is this the woman meant?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: That your Landlady?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I know not what to say.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Am I a person
To be your sport Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I do believe now certain
I am a knave; but how, or when --

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Bawd to this piece of pie meat.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: A poor Gentlewoman
That lies in Town, about Law business,
If it like your worships.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You shall have Law, believe it.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: I will show your mastership my case.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: By no means,
I had rather see a Custard.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: My dead husband
Left it even thus sir.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Bless mine eyes from blasting,
I was never so frighted with a case.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: And so sir --

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Enough, put up good velvet head.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What are you two now,
By your own free confessions?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What you shall think us,
Though to myself I am certain, and my life
Shall make that good and perfect, or fall with it.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: We are sure of nothing (Fred) that is the truth of it:
I do not think my name is Don John, nor dare not
Believe anything that concerns me, but my debts,
Nor those in way of payment: things are so carried,
What to entreat your Grace, or how to tell ye
We are, or we are not, is past my cunning,
But I would fain imagine we are honest,
And on my conscience, I should fight in it --

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thus then,
For we may be all abused.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: It is possible,
For how should this concern them?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Here let us part --
Until tomorrow this time: we to our way,
To make this doubt out, and you to your way;
Pawning our honours then to meet again,
When if she be not found.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: We stand engaged
To answer any worthy way we are called to.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We ask no more.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.l: Ye have done with us then?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: No Dame.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But is her name Constantia?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes a movable
Belonging to a friend of mine: come out Fiddler,
What say you to this Lady; be not fearful?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Saving the reverence of my Masters pleasure,
I say she is a whore, and that she has robbed him,
Hoping his hurts would kill him.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.l: Who provoked me?
Nay sirra squeak, I will see your treble strings
Tied up too; if I hang, I will spoil your piping,
Your sweet face shall not save ye.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Thou damned impudence,
And thou dried devil; where is the Officer?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: He is here sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Lodge these safe till I send for them;
Let none come to them, nor no noise be heard
Of where they are, or why: away.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: By this hand
A handsome whore: Now will I be arrested,
And brought home to this officers: a stout whore,
I love such stirring ware: pox on this business,
A man must haunt out morsels for another,
And starve himself: a quick-eyed whore, that is wild-fire,
And makes the blood dance through the veins like billows.
I will reprieve this whore.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well, good luck with ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: As much attend your Grace.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Tomorrow certain --

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: If we out-live this night sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come Don John,
We have something now to do.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I am sure I would have.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If she be not found, we must fight.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I am glad of it,
I have not fought a great while.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If we die --

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: There is so much money saved in lechery.

body.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio below, and Vechio above.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It should be hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Your grace is right,
This is the house I know it.

sp.speaker: Voch.
sp.l: Grace?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is further
By the description we received.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Good my Lord the Duke,
Believe me, for I know it certainly,
This is the very house.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: My Lord the Duke?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Pray heaven this man Prove right now.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Believe it, he is a most sufficient Scholar,
And can do rare tricks this way; for a figure,
Or raising an appearance, whole Christendom
Has not a better; I have heard strange wonders of him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But can he show us where she is?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Most certain,
And for what cause too she departed.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Knock then,
For I am great with expectation,
Till this man satisfy me: I fear the Spaniards,
Yet they appear brave fellows: can he tell us?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: With a wet finger, whether they be false.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Away then.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Who is within here?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Your Grace may enter.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How can he know me?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He knows all.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: And you sir.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: What do you call his name?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why, Peter Vechio.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: They say he can raise devils,
Can he make them
Tell truth too, when he has raised them? for believe it,
These devils are the lyingest Rascals.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He can compel them.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: With what? can he
Tie squibs in their tails, and fire the truth out?
Or make them eat a bawling Puritan,
Whose sanctified zeal shall rumble like an Earthquake?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: With Spells man?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Aye with spoons as soon, dost thou think
The devil such an Ass as people make him?
Such a poor coxcomb? such a penny foot post?
Compelled with cross and pile to run of errands?
With Asteroth, and Behemoth, and Belfagor?
Why should he shake at sounds, that lives in a smiths forge?
Or if he do --

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Without all doubt he does Iohn.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Why should not Bilbo raise him, or a pair of bullyons,
They go as big as any? or an unshod Car,
When he goes tumble, tumble over the stones,
Like Anacreons drunken verses, make us tremble?
These make as fell a noise; methinks the colic
Well handled, and fed with small beere---

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is the virtue --

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: The virtue? nay, and goodness fetch him up once,
He has lost a friend of me; the wise old Gentleman
Knows when, and how; I will lay this hand to two pence,
Let all the Conjurers in Christendom,
With all their spells, and vertues call upon him,
And I but think upon a wench, and follow it,
He shall be sooner mine than theirs; where is virtue?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou art the most sufficient, (I will say for thee)
Not to believe a thing --

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: O sir, slow credit
Is the best child of knowledge; I will go with ye,
And if he can do anything, I will think
As you would have me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let us enquire along ,
For certain we are not far off.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Nor much nearer.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: You lost her yesternight.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: How think you sir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is your name Vechio?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And you can show me
These things you promise.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Your graces word bound to me,
No hand of Law shall seize me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: As I live sir --

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: And as I live, that can do something too sir.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I take your promises: stay here a little,
Till I prepare some Ceremonies, and I will satisfy ye.
The Ladies name is Constantia?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yes

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I come straight.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sure he is a learned man.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The most now living;
Did your grace mark when we told all these circumstances,
How ever and anon he bolted from us
To use his studies help?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now I think rather
To talk with some familiar.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Not unlikely,
For sure he has them subject.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How could he else
Tell when she went, and who went with her?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Or hit upon mine honour: or assure me
The Lady loved me dearly?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It was so.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Now,
I do beseech your Grace sit down, and you sir;
Nay pray sit close like brothers.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A rare fellow.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: And what ye see, stir not at, nor use a word,
Until I ask ye; for what shall appear
Is but weak apparition and thin air
Not to be held, nor spoken too.

body.stage: John, Fredrick, and a Servant within.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We are counselled --

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: What noise is that without there?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: We must speak with him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He is busy Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: That is all one friend,
We must, and will speak with him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Let them in sir,
We know their tongues and business, it is our own,
And in this very cause that we now come for,
They also come to be instructed.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Let them in then:
Sit down, I know your meaning.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The Duke before us,
Now we shall sure know something.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Not a question,
But make your eyes, your tongues --

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: This is a strange juggler,
Neither indent before hand for his payment,
Nor know the breadth of the business; sure his devil
Comes out of Lapland were they sell men winds,
For dead drink, and old doublets.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, he conjures.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Let him, he cannot raise my devil.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prithee peace.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Appear, appear,
And you soft winds so clear,
That dance upon the leaves, and make them sing
Gentle love-lays to the Spring,
Gilding all the vales below
With your verdure as ye blow,
Raise these forms from under-ground
With a soft and happy sound.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: This is an honest Conjurer, and a pretty Poet;
I like his words well, there is no bombast in them,
But do you think now, he can cudgel up the devil,
With this short staff of Verses?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace the spirits --

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Nay, if they be no worse --

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Do ye know these faces?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit still upon your lives then: and mark what follows;
Away, away.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: These devils do not paint sure?
Have they no sweeter shapes in hell?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hark now Iohn.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Aye marry, this moves something like, this devil
Carries some metal in her gate.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I find ye,
You would see her face unvailed?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Be uncovered.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: See how she blushes.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Fredrick,
This devil for my money; this is she Boy,
Why dost thou shake? I burn.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit still, and silent.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: She looks back at me; now she smiles sir.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I must rise, or I burst.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Ye see what follows --

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O gentle sir this shape again.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I cannot,
It is all disolved again: this was the figure.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: The very same sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: No hope once more to see it?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: You might have kept it longer, had ye spared it,
Now it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No means to find it?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: Yes that there is: sit still a while, there is wine
To thaw the wonder from your hearts: drink well sir.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: This Conjurer is a right good fellow too,
A lad of mettle; two such devils more
Would make me a Conjurer: what wine is it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hollock.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: The devil is in it then, look how it dances?
Well, if I be --

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: We are all before ye,
That is your best comfort sir.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: By the mass brave wine;
Nay, and the Devils live in this hell, I dare venture
Within these two months yet to be delivered
Of a large legion of them.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Here he comes,
Silence of all sides Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vec.
sp.l: Good your grace,
Observe a stricter temper, and you too gallants,
You will be deluded all else. This merry devil
That next appears, for such a one you will find it,
Must be called up by a strange incantation,
A Song, and I must sing it: pray bear with me,
And pardon my rude pipe; for yet ere parting
Twenty to one I please ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We are armed Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nor shall you see us more transgress.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What thinkest thou
Now Iohn?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Why, now do I think Fredrick,
(And if I think amiss heaven pardon me,)
This honest Conjurer, with some four or five
Of his good fellow devils, and myself,
Shall be yet drunk ere midnight.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, he conjures.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Why, this is the Song Fredrick: twenty pound now
To see but our Don Gillian.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace it appears.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I cannot peace: devils in French hoods Fredrick?
Satan's old Syringes?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What is this?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: She, Boy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: She, Boy, I say.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: She, boy.
The very child too Fredrick;

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She laughs on us
Aloud Iohn, has the devil these affections?
I do believe it is she indeed.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Stand still.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I will not;
Who calls Jeronimo from his naked bed?
Sweet Lady, was it you? If thou beest the devil,
First, having crossed self, to keep out wildfire,
Then said some special prayers to defend me
Against thy most unhallowed hood: have at thee.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Hold sir, I am no devil.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: That is all one.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I am your very Landlady.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I defy thee:
Thus as Saint Dunstan blew the devils nose
With a pair of tongs, even so right worshipful --

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Sweet son, I am old Gillion.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This is no spirit.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Art thou old Gillian, flesh and bone?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I am Son.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit still sir, now I will show you all.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Where is thy bottle?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Here, I beseech ye son --

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: For I know the devil
Cannot assume that shape.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is she Iohn, certain --

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: A hogs pox on your mouldy chaps, what make you
Tumbling and juggling here?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I am quit now Seignior,
For all the pranks you played, and railings at me,
For to tell true, out of a trick I put
Upon your high behaviours, which was a lie,
But then it served my turn, I drew the Lady
Unto my kinsmans here, only to torture
Your Don-ships for a day or two; and secure her
Out of all thoughts of danger: here she comes now.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: May I yet speak?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes, and embrace her too,
For one that loves you dearer --

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O my sweetest.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Blush not, I will not chide ye.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: To add more
Unto the joy I know, I bring ye, see sir,
The happy fruit of all our vows.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Heavens blessing
Be round about thee ever.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Pray bless me too ,
For if your grace be well instructed this way,
You will find the keeping half the getting.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I will tell ye that anon.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: It is true, this Gentleman
Has done a charity worthy your favour,
And let him have it dear sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My best Lady
She has, and ever shall have: so must you sir,
To whom I am equal bound, as to my being.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Your Graces humble servants --

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why kneel you sir?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: For pardon for my boldness: yet it was harmless
And all the art I have sir; those your grace saw
Which you thought spirits, were my neighbours children
Whom I instruct in Grammar, here, and Music;
Their shapes, the peoples fond opinions,
Believing I can conjure, and oft repairing
To know of things stolen from them, I keep about me,
And always have in readiness; by conjecture
Out of their own confessions, I oft tell them
Things, that by chance have fallen out so: which way
(Having the persons here, I knew you sought for)
I wrought upon your grace: my end is mirth,
And pleasing, if I can, all parties.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I believe it,
For you have pleased me truly: so well pleased me,
That when I shall forget it --

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Here is old Antonio,
I spied him at a window, coming mainly
I know about his whore, the man you light on,
As you discovered unto me: good your Grace,
Let us stand by all, it will be a mirth above all,
To observe his pelting fury.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: About a wench sir?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: A young whore that has robbed him.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: But do you know sir,
Where she is?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, and will make that perfect --

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I am instructed well then.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: If he come
To have a devil showed him, by all means
Let me be he, I can roar rarely.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Be so,
But take heed to his anger.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Slip in quickly,
There you shall find suites of all sorts: when I call,
Be ready and come forward.
Who is there come in?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you the Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sir I can do a little
That way, if you please to employ me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Presently show me a devil that can tell --

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Where your wench is.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are in the right; as also where the Fiddler
That was consenting to her.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit ye there sir,
Ye shall know presently: can ye pray heartily?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why, is your devil so furious?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I must show ye
A form, may chance affright ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He must fart fire then:
Take you no care for me.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Ascend Asterth,
sp.stage: Enter Don John like a Spirit.
sp.l: Why, when, appear I say -- Now question him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is my whore Don devil?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Gone to China,
To be the great Chams Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That is a lie devil:
Where are my jewels?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Pawned for Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That may be; where is the Fiddler?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Condemned to the Gallows,
For robbing of a Mill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The lyingest devil
That ever I dealt withal, and the unlikeliest:
What was that Rascal hurt me?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who was he?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do ye here conjurer,
Dare you venture your devil?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then I will venture my dagger;
Have at your devils pate: do ye mew?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Hold there,
I do command ye hold.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is this the devil?
Why Conjurer --

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: He has been a devil to you sir.
But now you shall forget all: your whore is safe,
And all your Jewels: your Boy too.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Now the devil indeed
Lay his ten claws upon thee, for my pate
Finds what it is to be a fend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: All safe?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pray ye know this person: all is right now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your grace
May now command me then: but where is my whore?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Ready to go to whipping.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My whore whipped?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, your whore without doubt Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whipped? pray Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why, would you have her once more rob ye? the young boy
You may forgive, he was enticed.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: The Whore sir,
Would rather carry pity: a handsome Whore.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A Gentleman I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Let us in all,
And if we see contrition in your whore sir,
Much may be done.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now my dear fair, to you,
And the full consummation of my Vow.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.l: Aptness for mirth to all, this instant night
Thalia hath prepared for your delight,
Her choice and curious Viands, in each part,
Seasoned with rarities of wit, as Art;
Nor fear I to be taxed for a vain boast,
My promise will find credit with the most,
When they know Ingenuous Fletcher made it, he
Being in himself a perfect Comedy.
And some sit here, I doubt not dare aver,
Living he made that house a Theatre
Which he pleased to frequent; and thus much we
Could not but pay to his loud memory.
For ourselves we do entreat that you would not
Expect strange turns, and windings in the Plot,
Objects of State, and now and then a Rhyme,
To gall particular persons, with the time;
Or that his towering Muse hath made her flight
Nearer your apprehension than your fight:
But if that sweet expressions, quick conceit,
Familiar language, fashioned to the weight
Of such as speak it, have the power to raise
Your grace to us, with Trophies to his praise:
We may profess, presuming on his skill,
If his Chances please not you, our fortune's ill.

sp.speaker: Epilogue
sp.l: We have not held you long, nor do I see
One brow in this selected company
Assuring a dislike, our pains were eased,
Could we be confident that all rise pleased:
But such ambition soars too high: If we
Have satisfied the best, and they agree
In a fair censure, We have our reward;
And in them armed, desire no surer guard.
